title: Getting to Know PNH Warning Signs
author: Lisa Fields

content: Because paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is a rare blood disorder that many people don’t know about, it may take someone months or years to get a proper diagnosis.

About half of people with PNH have a telltale symptom: Reddish or dark-colored pee. This happens because the disorder causes red blood cells to break apart, which releases bright red hemoglobin. The body gets rid of this hemoglobin through the urine.
If you tell your doctor about red or dark-colored pee, it may make PNH easier to diagnose. But about half of people don’t have that symptom.
But PNH has other signs that could help you or your doctor zero in on it:

content_blocks.text: Because paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is a rare blood disorder that many people don’t know about, it may take someone months or years to get a proper diagnosis.

About half of people with PNH have a telltale symptom: Reddish or dark-colored pee. This happens because the disorder causes red blood cells to break apart, which releases bright red hemoglobin. The body gets rid of this hemoglobin through the urine.
If you tell your doctor about red or dark-colored pee, it may make PNH easier to diagnose. But about half of people don’t have that symptom.
But PNH has other signs that could help you or your doctor zero in on it:

sections.heading: Broken Red Blood Cells
content: In people with PNH, part of your immune system targets abnormal red blood cells, breaking apart those cells. This happens when a gene (called PIGA) mutates in the bone marrow’s stem cells. When the stem cells have mutations, they make red blood cells that don't have an important protein that usually keeps them safe from the immune system.
When red blood cells break apart, they may cause dark-colored urine, along with:

content_blocks.text: In people with PNH, part of your immune system targets abnormal red blood cells, breaking apart those cells. This happens when a gene (called PIGA) mutates in the bone marrow’s stem cells. When the stem cells have mutations, they make red blood cells that don't have an important protein that usually keeps them safe from the immune system.
When red blood cells break apart, they may cause dark-colored urine, along with:

sections.heading: Anemia
content: When red blood cells are destroyed faster than the body can replace them, you might get anemia, a low count of red blood cells. People with PNH and anemia could have:
bullets: Trouble breathing during or after exercise

content_blocks.text: When red blood cells are destroyed faster than the body can replace them, you might get anemia, a low count of red blood cells. People with PNH and anemia could have:
associated_bullets: Trouble breathing during or after exercise

sections.heading: Blood Clots
content: Doctors aren’t sure why, but people with PNH often form blood clots too easily. It may be because people with PNH make abnormal blood platelets, which leads to more clotting.
About one-third of people with PNH get blood clots.
These can be dangerous because they keep blood from flowing properly and carrying oxygen around your body. Blood clots might also block the blood flow to different organs completely.
That could lead to a heart attack, stroke, liver damage, or organ failure.
What might signal a blood clot? If a blood clot affects your:
bullets: Arm or leg - it may become sore, warm, and painful
Liver - you could get jaundice (yellow skin and eyes), belly pain, or liver problems
Brain - it may cause headaches or problems with mental skills
Lungs - you might have trouble breathing, shortness of breath, heart palpitations, or chest pain

sections.heading: Blood Clots
content: Doctors aren’t sure why, but people with PNH often form blood clots too easily. It may be because people with PNH make abnormal blood platelets, which leads to more clotting.
About one-third of people with PNH get blood clots.
These can be dangerous because they keep blood from flowing properly and carrying oxygen around your body. Blood clots might also block the blood flow to different organs completely.
That could lead to a heart attack, stroke, liver damage, or organ failure.
What might signal a blood clot? If a blood clot affects your:
bullets: Arm or leg - it may become sore, warm, and painful
Liver - you could get jaundice (yellow skin and eyes), belly pain, or liver problems
Brain - it may cause headaches or problems with mental skills
Lungs - you might have trouble breathing, shortness of breath, heart palpitations, or chest pain

sections.heading: Low Blood Platelet Counts
content: In addition to red blood cells, bone marrow stem cells make blood platelets and white blood cells. In some people with PNH, the mutated bone marrow stem cells don’t make enough healthy platelets. This may cause clotting problems. You may have:
bullets: Signs of bleeding under your skin (such as small red spots)
Heavy bleeding, even from minor cuts or scrapes
Trouble stopping the bleeding from minor cuts or scrapes
Gums that bleed easily after dental work or brushing

sources: Aplastic Anemia and MDS International Foundation: “PNH -- Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria,” “PNH -- Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria: Symptoms.”
National Organization for Rare Diseases: “Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria.”
European Society for Blood and Marrow Transplantation: “Understanding PNH.”
meta_description: Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria is a hard-to-diagnose blood disorder. Find out about symptoms of PNH.
